title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #543: Random Subset Sums in Abelian Groups**

Define f(N) as the minimal k such that a random k-subset of an abelian group of size N spans all elements via subset sums with probability ≥ 1/2.

**Question**: Is f(N) ≤ log₂ N + o(log log N)?

**Known**: f(N) ≤ log₂ N + O(log log N) (Erdős-Rényi 1965)

**Erdős's Belief**: NO - the O(log log N) term is optimal.
mathContext: This problem connects probability theory with additive combinatorics. It asks how many random elements are needed to generate all subset sums in a group.

title: Subset Sums
content:
**subsetSums A**: The set of all elements expressible as ∑_{x ∈ S} x for some subset S ⊆ A.

This captures what elements can be 'reached' from A via subset sums.
mathContext: Subset sums are fundamental in additive combinatorics. The subset sum problem (deciding if a target is reachable) is NP-complete.

title: Spanning Set
content:
**IsSpanningSet A**: A set A spans G if every element of G is a subset sum of A.

Equivalently: subsetSums A = G.
mathContext: This is analogous to generating sets in group theory, but uses subset sums instead of arbitrary combinations.

title: Spanning Probability
content:
**spanningProbability G k**: The fraction of k-subsets of G that span all of G.

We want this probability ≥ 1/2.
mathContext: This is a uniform probability over all k-subsets, counting how many are 'good' (spanning).

title: Minimal Spanning Size
content:
**minimalSpanningSize G**: The minimal k such that a random k-subset spans G with probability ≥ 1/2.

This is f(N) for a specific group G of size N.
mathContext: Uses Nat.find to get the minimal k, which exists since the full group certainly spans.

title: The Function f(N)
content:
**f(N)**: The supremum of minimalSpanningSize over all abelian groups of size N.

This is the function from the problem statement - the worst-case over all groups.
mathContext: The supremum ensures f(N) captures the hardest group structure for subset sum spanning.

title: Erdős-Rényi Upper Bound (1965)
content:
**erdos_renyi_upper_bound**:

f(N) ≤ log₂ N + C · log(log N) for some constant C > 0.

This is the main known result, establishing the O(log log N) upper bound.
mathContext: From [ErRe65]. Uses probabilistic counting to show most random sets of this size span the group.

title: The Little-o Conjecture
content:
**LittleOConjecture**: For every ε > 0, eventually f(N) ≤ log₂ N + ε · log log N.

This asks: can O(log log N) be improved to o(log log N)?
mathContext: If true, the log log N term is not inherent and can be made arbitrarily small (relative to log log N).

title: Erdős's Counter-Conjecture
content:
**ErdosCounterConjecture**: There exists ε > 0 such that infinitely many N have f(N) > log₂ N + ε · log log N.

Erdős believed this is TRUE - the log log N term is necessary.
mathContext: This would establish that some groups inherently require the extra log log N term due to collision effects.

title: Conjectures are Complementary
content:
**conjectures_complementary**: LittleOConjecture ↔ ¬ErdosCounterConjecture

The two conjectures are logical negations. Exactly one must be true.
mathContext: This is a logical equivalence showing the problem has a binary answer.

title: Naive Lower Bound
content:
**naive_lower_bound**: f(N) ≥ log₂ N - 1

A k-subset has at most 2^k subset sums, so we need 2^k ≥ N to cover all elements.
mathContext: This is an information-theoretic lower bound - you can't cover more elements than you have subset sums.

title: Cyclic Group Case
content:
**f_cyclic(N)**: The spanning threshold for cyclic groups ℤ/Nℤ.

Cyclic groups may have special structure that makes spanning easier or harder.
mathContext: Cyclic groups are the simplest abelian groups. The problem asks about all abelian groups, not just cyclic ones.

title: Prime Order Groups
content:
**prime_case_structure**: For prime p, if |A| ≥ p in ℤ/pℤ, then A spans.

This is because ℤ/pℤ has only p elements, so A = ℤ/pℤ.
mathContext: Prime order groups are fields, giving additional structure. But the interesting case is when |A| << p.

title: Problem Summary
content:
**Erdős Problem #543: OPEN**

**Question**: Is f(N) ≤ log₂ N + o(log log N)?

**Known**:
- Upper: f(N) ≤ log₂ N + O(log log N) (Erdős-Rényi)
- Lower: f(N) ≥ log₂ N - O(1)

**Erdős's Belief**: NO - the O(log log N) is tight.
mathContext: The gap between O(log log N) and o(log log N) is the key open question.
